title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" introduces screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury under Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code. The Act "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" mandates a screening program for eligible veterans to detect symptoms of traumatic brain injury. The Secretary must submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding the number of veterans screened. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, detailing the number of veterans screened for traumatic brain injury symptoms, the prevalence of such symptoms, and recommendations for improving care and services for affected veterans. The Secretary is mandated to submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, detailing the number of veterans screened for traumatic brain injury symptoms, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for improving care. Additionally, a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation is to be developed, including residential, community, and home-based components with interdisciplinary treatment teams. The Secretary is required to develop a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation, including residential, community, and home-based components with interdisciplinary treatment teams. The program will be carried out in four geographically dispersed polytrauma network sites designated by the Secretary, and eligible veterans can receive care under this program. The Secretary will implement a program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation in four designated polytrauma network sites. Eligible veterans must have served in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War. The program developed under subsection (a) is for veterans eligible for care under this chapter who served in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War, have moderate to severe traumatic brain injury, and are unable to manage daily activities without assistance. The program is for veterans who served in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War, have moderate to severe traumatic brain injury, and need assistance with daily activities. The Secretary must report on the program's operation and the number of veterans receiving care annually. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs regarding a program for veterans with traumatic brain injury. The report must include details on the program's operation, the number of veterans receiving care, and the annual cost of operating the program. Additionally, traumatic brain injury transition offices are to be established at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate health-care provision. The Secretary must submit an annual report on a program for veterans with traumatic brain injury, including details on operation, number of veterans receiving care, and annual operating costs. Traumatic brain injury transition offices are to be established at Department polytrauma network sites to coordinate health-care provision for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary will establish a site to coordinate health-care and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. Cooperative agreements will be made with public or private entities for neurobehavioral rehabilitation programs. Additionally, a traumatic brain injury registry will be established and maintained by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry for individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom with symptoms. The Registry, also known as the Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry, will list individuals who served in Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom with symptoms of traumatic brain injury and seek care or compensation from the Department. The Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry includes individuals with symptoms of traumatic brain injury from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom who seek care or compensation from the Department. Relevant medical data and information may be included with permission from the individual. The Secretary may include relevant medical data and information in the Registry with permission from individuals or if they are deceased. Individuals listed will be notified of significant research developments on the health consequences of military service in Operation Enduring Freedom. The Secretary can add medical data to the Registry with consent or for deceased individuals. Those listed will be informed of research updates on health effects of military service in Operation Enduring Freedom and Operation Iraqi Freedom. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, includes provisions for screening, rehabilitation, transition offices, and a registry for traumatic brain injuries. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
